msContents.textLang: Middle English (Buckinghamshire dialect, LALME LP 6670) with Latin

msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.title: Canterbury Tales
msItem.rubric: Here beginneth the Prolog of the Tales of Caunterbury
msItem.incipit:
Whan that Aprill with his showres swote
The drought of Marche hath perced þe rote
msItem.explicit:
Beth fructuose and that litul space
And to done wele god sende yow his grace

msItem.title: The General Prologue
msItem.incipit:
Whan that Aprill with his showres swote
The drought of Marche hath perced þe rote
msItem.explicit:
Now late vs ride and herkeneth what I say
And with that worde we riden forth oure wey

msItem.title: The Knight’s Tale
msItem.rubric: Here beginneth the Knightes tale
msItem.incipit:
Whilom as old stories tellen vs
There was a duke þat hight Thesius
msItem.explicit:
Þus endith Palamoun and Emely
And god saue al þis company
msItem.finalRubric: here endeth þe knightez tale
msItem.note: On fol. 33v, I. 2837–46 are repeated after I. 2885; bracketed and notated vacat.

msItem.title: The Knight–Miller link
msItem.rubric: and beginneth þe prolog of þe Miller is tale
msItem.incipit:
Whan þat þe kniȝt had þus his tale tolde
In al þe rowte nas þere yong ne olde
msItem.explicit:
Aviseth you and put me oute of blame
And eke men shuld make non ernest of game
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the prolog of the Millers tale

msItem.title: The Miller’s Tale
msItem.incipit:
Whilom þer was dwelling at Oxenford
A riche knof þat gestes held to bord
msItem.explicit:
And Nicholas is scalded in the toute
This tale is done and god saue al þe route
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe myllers tale of hende Nicholas & absolon

msItem.title: The Reeve’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And next beginneth the Prolog of þe Carpenters tale
msItem.incipit:
Whan folk had loughen at þis nice caas
Of absoloun and hende Nicholas
msItem.explicit:
He can wel in myn ey finde a stalke
But in his own he can not se a balke
msItem.finalRubric: here endeth the Prolog of the Carpenters tale

msItem.title: The Reeve’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And next beginneth þe Carpenters tale of þe Miller of Trumpyngdoun
msItem.incipit:
At Trumpingtoun not fer fro Canterbrigge
þere goth a broke and ouer þat a brigge
msItem.explicit:
Saue al þis compani grete and smale
Thus haue I quite þe millers tale
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe Carpenters tale of þe Miller of Trympingdoun

msItem.title: The Introduction to the Man of Law’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And next biginneth þe prolog of þe man of lawes tale
msItem.incipit:
Oure host sawe wel þat þe briȝt son
The ark of his artificiall day hath y ron
msItem.explicit:
And with þat worde with a sobre chere
Bigan his tale as ye shall aftre here

msItem.title: The Man of Law’s Prologue
msItem.incipit:
O hateful harme condicion of pouerte
With thirst with colde with hongre so confounded
msItem.explicit:
Were not a marchuante þat gone is man a yere
Me taught a tale which ye shal here
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe Prolog of the man of lawes tale

msItem.title: The Man of Law’s Tale
msItem.rubric: next biginneth the man of lawe is tale of Quene Constance
msItem.incipit:
IN Surry whilom dwelled a company
Of chapmen riche and þere to sadde and true
msItem.explicit:
Ioy aftre wo gouerne vs in his grace
And kepe vs all that arn in þis place Amen
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe man of lawes tale of Constance

msItem.title: The Cook’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And next biginneth þe prolog before the Cokys tale
msItem.incipit:
The Coke of londoun whiles þe ryve spak
ffor Ioly he þoȝt to haue claued him in þe bake
msItem.explicit:
And þere with all þey lough and made chere
And seid his tale as ye shall aftre here
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe Prolog of þe Cokes tale

msItem.title: The Cook’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And next bigynneth þe Cokes tale of þe prentise of london
msItem.incipit:
A prentise dwelled whilom in oure Cite
Of a craft of vvitelers was hee
msItem.explicit:
And had a wife þat held for contenaunce
A shop and swifed for his sustenaunce
But here of I will passe as nowe
And of yong Gamelyne I will tell yowe

msItem.title: Gamelyn
msItem.incipit:
Sit and lysthen & herkeneth a right
And ye shal her of a doughti knight
msItem.explicit:
And so shall we all may þer no man fle
God god bring vs to þe ioy that ever shal be Amen
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe Cokes tale of þe prentise of londoun

msItem.title: The ‘Epilogue’ of the Man of Law’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And next bigynneth þe prolog befor þe squiers tale
msItem.incipit:
Oure hoste vpon his stirop stode Anon
And seid good men herkeneth euery chone
msItem.explicit:
Ne phisik ne termies queynt of lawe
Ther is but litul latyn in my mawe
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe prolog of þe squiers tale

msItem.title: The Squire’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And next bigynneþe þe squiers tale of þe horse of Brasse
msItem.incipit:
At Sarri in þe londe of Tartary
There dwelt a king þat werraied vpon russy
msItem.explicit:
Appollo woleth vp his chare so high
Til þe god mercurious hous þe sligh
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit 2ª pars

msItem.note: Blank. At least the following two folios, presumably blank, have been cut away, leaving stubs. Only a catchphrase, here endeth, on the final verso, fol. 84v.

msItem.title: The ‘Squire–Franklin Link’
msItem.rubric: Here endeth þe Squiers tale of þe horse of bras. And next bigynneþe þe prolog of þe Marchauntes tale
msItem.incipit:
IN feith squier thou hast the wel quit
And gentilli I prayse wel þi witte
msItem.explicit:
I pray to god þat I mai plese yowe
Than wote I well my tale is gode I nogh
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe Prolog of the Marchauntez tale
msItem.note: The link here functions to conjoin the Squire’s and Merchant’s Tales, with Merchant appearing instead of Franklin in V.675, 696, and 699.

msItem.title: The Merchant’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And next biginneþe the Marchauntes tale of Ianuarij
msItem.incipit:
Whilom þere was dwelling in lumbard
A worthi knight þat born was in pauy
msItem.explicit:
Thus endeth here my tale of Ianuarie
God blisse vs and his moder seint Marie Amen
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe Marchauntes tale of Ianuarie & May

msItem.title: The ‘Merchant’s Endlink’
msItem.rubric: Here foloueth þe wordes of oure Hoost to the ffrankeleyn
msItem.incipit:
Ey goddis merci seid oure oost þo
Now sich a wife I pray god kepe me fro
msItem.explicit:
And eke my wit suffiseth not there to
To tellen all wherefor my tale is do

msItem.title: The ‘Squire’s Headlink’
msItem.rubric: Prolog of þe ffrankelyn
msItem.incipit:
Sir ffrankeleyn come ner if it your will be
And sei vs a tale for certes ye
msItem.explicit:
Haue me excused if that I speke a mys
Mi wil is good and lo my tale is this

msItem.title: The Franklin’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: Here beginneth þe Prolog of the ffrankeleyn
msItem.incipit:
This olde gentel Britons in hire daies
Of diuerse auenturs maden laies
msItem.explicit:
My spirit feleth nat of such matere
But if you list my tale shall ye here

msItem.title: The Franklin’s Tale
msItem.rubric: Narrat
msItem.incipit:
In Armorik þat called is Bretaine
There was a knight þat loued & did his paine
msItem.explicit:
Now telleth me er ye ferther wende
I can no more my tale is at an ende
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe ffrankeleyns tale of þe Rokkes of Bretaigne

msItem.title: The Wife of Bath’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And next begynneth þe prolog of þe wife of Bath
msItem.incipit:
Experience þough none auctorite
Were in þis world is right y nogh for me
msItem.explicit:
If I haue licence of þis worthi Frere
Yis dame quod he tell forth & I wil here
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe Prolog of þe Wife of Bathe

msItem.title: The Wife of Bath’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And next biginneth the tale of þe Wife of Bath
msItem.incipit:
IN þe olde daies of King Artour
Of which Britones speke grete honour
msItem.explicit:
And olde and angry nygardes of dispense
God sende hem sone verry pestilence
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the Wifes tale of Bathe

msItem.title: The Friar’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And next biginneth the Prolog of the ffrere
msItem.incipit:
This worthi lymytoure þis noble frere
He made alwey a loward chere
msItem.explicit:
And aftreward he seid vnto the ffrere
Telleth forth youre tale myn own maister dere
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe prolog of the ffreres tale

msItem.title: The Friar’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And next biginneth þe ffreres tale of the Somnoure
msItem.incipit:
Whilom þere was dwelling in my contre
An Archdiacon a man of hie degre
msItem.explicit:
And praieth þat þies somnours him repent
Of theire mysdedes or þe fende hem hent
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe ffreres tale of the Somnoure

msItem.title: The Sommoner’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And next biginneth the Prolog of the Somnours
msItem.incipit:
This Somnour in his stiropp ful high he stode
Vpon þis ffrere his hert was so wode
msItem.explicit:
God saue yow all saue this cursed frere
Mi prolong wol I ende in þis maner
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe Prolog of the Somnours tale

msItem.title: The Summoner’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And next biginneth the Somnours tale
msItem.incipit:
Lordinges þere is in yorkshire as I gesse
A Merssh contre called holdernesse
msItem.explicit:
And Iankyn hath wonnen a newe gown
Mi tale is don we be al most atte town
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe tale of the Somnour

msItem.title: The Prologue of the Second Nun’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And next beginneth the Prolog of the Nonne
msItem.incipit:
The mynistre of þe norice vnto vices
Which men callen in englissh Idelnesse
msItem.explicit:
And brennyng euer in charite ful bright
Now I haue yow declared what she hight
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe Prolog of the Nonne

msItem.title: The Second Nun’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And next beginneth þe tale of the Nonne of the life of Seint Cecile
msItem.incipit:
THis maiden bright Cecile as hire life saith
Was comen of Romains & of noble kinde
msItem.explicit:
In which into this day in noble wise
Men doon to crist and to þis saint servise
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe ij Non is tale

msItem.title: The Canon’s Yeoman’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And next beginneth the Prolog of the Chanons yoman
msItem.incipit:
Whan ended was þe life of seint Cecile
Er we fulli hadde reden fyve myle
msItem.explicit:
Syns that my lorde is gon I wol not spare
Siche þing as I know I shal declare
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the Prolog of the Chanons yoman

msItem.title: The Canon’s Yeoman’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And next beginneth þe tale of the Chanons yoman
msItem.incipit:
WIth þis Chanon dwelt haue I seuen yere
And of his sciens am I neuer þe nere
msItem.explicit:
And þere a pointe for ended is my tale
God send eueri true man bote of his bale
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the Chanons yomans tale

msItem.rubric: And next biginneth the Prolog of the Doctour of phisik
msItem.quote:
Whan this yoman his tale ended hadde
Of this fals Chanon which was so badde
Oure oost gan sey treuly and certaine
This prest was begiled sothli to sayne
He wenyng for to be a philosophre
Til he right no gold left in his cofre
And sothli þis prest had a litull Iape
This cursed Chanon put in his hode an Ape
But al this passe I ouer as nowe
Sir doctour of phisik I pray you
Tell vs a tale of some honest matere
Hit shal be don if ye wol it here
Seid þis doctoure and his tale began anon
Now goode men quod he herkeneth eueri chon
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe prolog of the doctour of phisik

msItem.title: The Physician’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And next biginneth the tale of the doctour of phisik
msItem.incipit:
There was a knight as telleth liuius
That called was virginius
msItem.explicit:
Therefor I rede you this consail take
fforsaketh syn or syn you forsake
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the Doctour of Phisik tale

msItem.title: The ‘Host’s Words’/‘Physician–Pardoner Link’
msItem.rubric: And next biginneth the Prolog of the Pardoner
msItem.incipit:
Oure ost gan to swere as he were wode
Harow quod he bi nailes and be blode
msItem.explicit:
I graunte I wis quod he but I must thenk
Vpon som honest thing whiles I shall drink

msItem.title: The Pardoner’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: Here beginneth þe Prolog of the Pardoner
Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas Ad Timotheum vᵗᵒ
msItem.incipit:
Lordinges quod he in chirches whan I preche
I payn me to haue a hawteine speche
msItem.explicit:
Which I am wont to preche for to wyn
Now hold your pees my tale I wil begyn
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the Prolog of the Pardoner

msItem.title: The Pardoner’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And next beginneth þe Pardoners tale
msItem.incipit:
In fflaundres whilom was a company
Of yong folk that haunted foly
msItem.explicit:
And as we deden lete vs lagh and play
Anoon thei kissed and riden forth her way
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe Pardoners tale

msItem.title: The Clerk’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And next begynneth the Prolog of the Clerk of Oxenford
msItem.incipit:
O sir Clerk of Oxenford oure oost saide
ye ride as still & as koy as doth a maide
msItem.explicit:
Save þat he will conueyen his matere
But this is his tale as ye shal here
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the prolog of the Clerk

msItem.title: The Clerk’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And next beginneth the Clerkes tale
msItem.incipit:
There is at þe west side of Itayll
Doune at þe rote of vesulus þe colde
msItem.explicit:
Be ay of chere light as lefe on lynde
And late him care wepe wring and waile
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe Clerkis tale of Oxenford

msItem.rubric: And next beginneth þe Prolog of þe Shipman
msItem.quote:
Now frendes seid oure ooste so dere
How liketh you bi Iohn pardonere
ffor he hath vnbokled wele the male
He hath vs told right a thrifty tale
As touchyng of his mysgouernaunce
I pray to god if him goode chaunce
As ye haue herd of thies riatours thre
Now gentil maryner hertly I pray þe
Tel vs a goode tale and þat right A none
Hit shal be do by god and bi seint Ihone
Seid þis maryner as wel as I can
And right A none his tale he bigan
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe Prolog of the Shipman

msItem.title: The Shipman’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And next biginneth þe tale of þe Shipman
msItem.incipit:
A marchaunte whilom dwelt at seint Denys
That riche was for siche men hold him wise
msItem.explicit:
Thus endeth now my tale and god vs sende
Tellinges I nogh vnto our lyues ende
msItem.finalRubric: Here endith the tale of the Shipman

msItem.title: The ‘Shipman–Prioress Link’
msItem.rubric: And next begynneþ the Prolog of the Prioresse
msItem.incipit:
Wel said be corpus dominus quod oure hos
Now longe mote þou saile bi þe coost
msItem.explicit:
Now wil ye vouchesaue my lady dere
Gladly quod she and seid in þis manere

msItem.title: The Prioress’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: Here beginneth the tale of the Prioresse of Alma Redemptoris Domine dominus noster quia admirabile est nomen tuum in vniuersa terra
msItem.incipit:
O lorde oure lorde þi name how mervelous
Is in this large world spred quod she
msItem.explicit:
Right so fare I and therefore I yow pray
Gideth my songe þat I shal of you say

msItem.title: The Prioress’s Tale
msItem.rubric: ffabula
msItem.incipit:
There was in Asye in a grete Cite
A monge cristen folk a Iurie
msItem.explicit:
On vs his grete mercy multiplie
ffor reuerence of his moder marie Amen
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the tale of þe Prioresse

msItem.title: The Prologue to Sir Thopas
msItem.rubric: And next beginneþe the Prologg of Chauncere
msItem.incipit:
Whan seid was al þis miracle eueri man
All sobre was þat wondre was to se
msItem.explicit:
Ye that is good quod he now shal we here
Som dainte thing me thenketh be his chere
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the Prologg

msItem.title: The Sir Thopas
msItem.rubric: And next begynneth the tale of sire Thopas
msItem.incipit:
Listeth lordes in gode entent
I wil you tel verament
msItem.explicit:
As did þe knight sere percyuell
So worthely vnder wede
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the tale of sir Thopas
msItem.note: VII.852-4, 918 omitted; 805 left blank; 865 inserted in margin.

msItem.title: The ‘Thopas–Melibee Link’
msItem.rubric: And next biginneth the Prolog of Chaucer
msItem.incipit:
No more of þis for goddis dignite
Quod oure ooste for thou makist me
msItem.explicit:
And therefore herkeneth what I shal sey
And late me tell al my tale I pray
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the Prolog of the Chauncer

msItem.rubric: And next biginneth the tale of the Chauncer
msItem.incipit: A yong man called Mellibius
msItem.explicit: bring vs to þe blisse that neuer hathe ende. Amen.
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth Chaucers tale of Melibe and Dame Prudence

msItem.title: The Monk’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And next beginneth the Prolog of the Monke
msItem.incipit:
Whan ended was þe tale of Melibe
And of prudence and hir benignite
msItem.explicit:
As it now cometh to my remembraunce
Haue me excused of myn ignoraunce
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the Prolog of the Monke

msItem.title: The Monk’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And next biginneth the tale of þe Monke de Casibus virorum illustrium
msItem.incipit:
I will bewaile in maner of tragedy
The harme of hem þat stonde in hie degre
msItem.explicit:
ffor whan men trusteth hir þan wil she faile
And couer hir bright face with a cloude
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth þe Monkes tale de casibus virorum illustrissimum

msItem.title: The Nun’s Priest’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And next beginneth þe prolog of the Nonne Preste
msItem.incipit:
HO quod þe knight gode sir no more of this
That ye haue seid is right I now I wis
msItem.explicit:
And thus he seid to vs eueri chone
This swete prest this goodly man sir Iohn
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the prolog

msItem.title: The Nun’s Priest’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And next beginneth the Nonnes Prest tale of the Cok and of þe Foxe
msItem.incipit:
A Poor widow som dele stape in age
As whilom dwelling in a narow cage
msItem.explicit:
As seith my lorde so make vs al gode men
And bring vs all to his high blisse amen
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the Nonnes Prest tale
msItem.note: VII.2902, 2922 omitted; 3831-2, 2965-6, 3391-2 reversed; 2822, 3135 inserted in margin.

msItem.title: The Manciple’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And next begynneth þe Prolog of the Maunciple
msItem.incipit:
Wote ye not where stondeth a litel towne
Which is cleped bob vp and downe
msItem.explicit:
Tel on þou maunciple I the pray
Wele sir quod he herkeneth what I say
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the Prologg of the Maunciple

msItem.title: The Manciple’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And next beginneth the tale of the Maunciple
msItem.incipit:
Whan Phebus dwelt in þis erth here adowne
As olde bokis maketh mencioun
msItem.explicit:
Where so thou come amonges hie or lowe
Kepe wele thi tonge and thenk vpon the crowe
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the tale of the maunciple

msItem.title: The Parson’s Prologue
msItem.rubric: And next biginneth the Prolog of the Persones tale
msItem.incipit:
By that the maunciple hadde his tale ended
The son fro þe southe side is descended
msItem.explicit:
Beth fructuose and that litul space
And to done wele god sende yow his grace
msItem.finalRubric: Here endeth the Prologg of the Persones tale

msItem.title: The Parson’s Tale
msItem.rubric: And next biginneth the Persones tale
¶ Ieromias sexto⸝ State super vias et videte et interrogate de semitis antiquis que sit via bona et ambulate in ea et invenietis refrigerium animabus vestris
msItem.incipit: Oure swete lorde god of hevenn that no man wold
msItem.explicit: And he that wrote this boke also⸝ Amen. Qui cum patre
msItem.note: Omits parts of 8, 226, 242, 250, 273, 296–7. Names noted in margins.

supportDesc.collation: 1-108 (fols. 1-80), 118–3? (fols. 81-84; 5th, 6th, 7th cancelled, all presumably blank, with 6th and 7th stubs visible; 8th blank with catchword), 12–328 (fols. 85-252), 338–3 (fols. 253-257; 6th–8th cancelled, with at least two stubs visible). Catchwords on the final verso. Lettered signatures (beginning with a, a second series aa from fol. 157) usually visible though trimmed.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in plummet, written in 43 long lines, ruled space 185 110

handDesc.handNote: Written in an Anglicana bookhand, seemingly by a single scribe.

decoDesc.decoNote: Open with an eight-line initial W on a gold field, bordered with penwork and green acanthus scrollwork (fol. 1r).

Textual divisions, either the openings of prologues or tales, are marked by initials of two to four lines with penwork and borders. Versals in blue or gold, with red or blue penwork (Pächt and Alexander iii. 1060).
Rubricated incipits and explicits, running heads, and glosses.

binding.p: Fragment from the back of an earlier binding, labelled MSS D Hatton, inside the upper board. The second endleaf (fol. ii) has also been removed from this binding and pasted to a more recent endleaf.
Eighteenth century, brown suade leather over pasteboard.

history.provenance: Sixteenth-century inscriptions: William Hurst (fol. 9r), Wyllm Shirley (fol. 124r), Iohn Da (fol. 208r).
Capt. Charles Hatton (1635–after 1708) (inscribed, fol. ii recto); given to the:
history.acquisition: Bodleian Library, 1669: Hunt, ‘Historical Introduction’, in A Summary Catalogue, 1:xiv.

recordHist.source: Description by Andrew Dunning (August 2022), with contents revised from the Digital Index of Middle English Verse and reference to earlier published descriptions. Decoration, localization and date previously described in Pächt and Alexander (1973); also described in the Summary Catalogue: Summary Catalogue, Vol. 2 Part 2, p. 863 Summary Catalogue, Vol. 2 Part 2, p. 864

availability.p: This item will be on display in the exhibition "Chaucer Here and Now", Bodleian Libraries, Weston Library, 8 December 2023 – 28 April 2024. It will not be orderable between those dates or for a short period before or afterwards.

ref.title: A Digital Catalogue of the Pre-1500 Manuscripts and Incunables of the Canterbury Tales
